DataElement.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure Viable Cell Specimen Method Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the method used for testing cell viability.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure Viable Cell Specimen Method
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting._Capable of life or normal growth and development._The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid._A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis._A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Property.preferredDefinition: Capable of life or normal growth and development.:The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.:A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.:A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

Concepts.definition: Capable of life or normal growth and development.
The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.

A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.
A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Cell Specimen Viable Laboratory Procedure Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid._A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis._Capable of life or normal growth and development._Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting_Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A fluorescent nucleic acid dye which selectively binds GC sequences in double-stranded DNA. It has a molecular weight of 1270.5, an absorbance maximun at 546 nm, and emission maximum at 647 nm. It is commonly used to discriminate viable from non-viable cells.

Concepts.definition: A fluorescent nucleic acid dye which selectively binds GC sequences in double-stranded DNA. It has a molecular weight of 1270.5, an absorbance maximun at 546 nm, and emission maximum at 647 nm. It is commonly used to discriminate viable from non-viable cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not otherwise specified.: A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A fluorescent nucleic acid dye which binds only to double-stranded nucleic acids. It has a molecular weight of 668.4, an absorbance maximum of 535nm, and an emission maximum of 617 nm.  It is commonly used to determine the DNA content of a cell or to discriminate viable from non-viable cells.

Concepts.definition: A fluorescent nucleic acid dye which binds only to double-stranded nucleic acids. It has a molecular weight of 668.4, an absorbance maximum of 535nm, and an emission maximum of 617 nm.  It is commonly used to determine the DNA content of a cell or to discriminate viable from non-viable cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An acid azo dye commonly used as a stain to distinguish viable from non-viable cells. It turns dead cells blue and viable cells unstained. It is a known animal carcinogen and an experimental teratogen.

Concepts.definition: An acid azo dye commonly used as a stain to distinguish viable from non-viable cells. It turns dead cells blue and viable cells unstained. It is a known animal carcinogen and an experimental teratogen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A green-fluorescent dye that has the ability to penetrate apoptotic cells because of permeability changes associated with the loss in asymmetry of the plasma membrane. Once inside the cell, the dye binds to DNA.

Concepts.definition: A green-fluorescent dye that has the ability to penetrate apoptotic cells because of permeability changes associated with the loss in asymmetry of the plasma membrane. Once inside the cell, the dye binds to DNA.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A dark red, crystalline, non-volatile solid which fluoresces readily when exposed to ultraviolet light. It is a DNA intercalating agent and is commonly used as a marker for visualizing nucleic acids in electrophoresis and other methods of DNA separation and purification.

Concepts.definition: A dark red, crystalline, non-volatile solid which fluoresces readily when exposed to ultraviolet light. It is a DNA intercalating agent and is commonly used as a marker for visualizing nucleic acids in electrophoresis and other methods of DNA separation and purification.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Acridine Orange Staining Method And/Or Propidium Iodide

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Acridine Orange Staining Method And/Or Propidium Iodide
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A microscopy staining method that utilizes acridine orange, a fluorescent cationic dye that is selective for nucleic acids, to determine the presence of viable cells or microorganisms in a sample. Acridine orange interacts with RNA and DNA and the lysosomal compartment of cells.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options: A fluorescent nucleic acid dye which binds only to double-stranded nucleic acids. It has a molecular weight of 668.4, an absorbance maximum of 535nm, and an emission maximum of 617 nm.  It is commonly used to determine the DNA content of a cell or to discriminate viable from non-viable cells.

Concepts.definition: A microscopy staining method that utilizes acridine orange, a fluorescent cationic dye that is selective for nucleic acids, to determine the presence of viable cells or microorganisms in a sample. Acridine orange interacts with RNA and DNA and the lysosomal compartment of cells.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.

A fluorescent nucleic acid dye which binds only to double-stranded nucleic acids. It has a molecular weight of 668.4, an absorbance maximum of 535nm, and an emission maximum of 617 nm.  It is commonly used to determine the DNA content of a cell or to discriminate viable from non-viable cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique for counting, examining and sorting microscopic particles suspended in a stream of fluid.

Concepts.definition: A technique for counting, examining and sorting microscopic particles suspended in a stream of fluid.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: The mode or manner or orderly sequence of events of a process or procedure.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Cell Specimen Viable Laboratory Procedure Type
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid. Cells are highly variable and specialized in both structure and function, though all must at some stage replicate proteins and nucleic acids, utilize energy, and reproduce themselves.:Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.:Capable of life or normal growth and development.:A medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood, urine, or other substance from the body. Tests can help determine a diagnosis, plan treatment, check to see if treatment is working, or monitor the disease over time.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: The smallest units of living structure capable of independent existence, composed of a membrane-enclosed mass of protoplasm and containing a nucleus or nucleoid.

A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.
Capable of life or normal growth and development.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
